children.subject: Will this count as a CS Upper-Dic requirement or a Upper-div tech elective?

Just a tech-elective? or can it count as one of the 5 required upper-div CS classes? 

Thanks so much Lily :)
oh oops, thanks for asking for clarification! it will count as a CS upper div which will also count as a tech elective
This is something i reposted. Please contact the listed instructor.
I just heard from the instructor yesterday and updated this post. Students need to receive a code from him to enroll.
Do we need special permission to enroll? I was trying to add it on CalCentral but it wouldn't let me

history.content:
CS194-032 - Computing for Social Good (CCN: 67079)

Instructor: Barath Raghavan

Meeting Time and Place: M, 2-5 PM, 310 Soda Hall

Prerequisite: CS61B AND permission of instructor

Units: 4 units

Brief Description:

This course will focus on understanding computing's potential for good (and harm), and doing a concrete, semester-long independent project with a goal of real impact.  The topics will include ecological, social, energetic, and other challenges and the role computing can play in responding to them.  The course will be very different from CS 195 (Social Implications of Computing), which is more philosophical; this course will be much more practically-oriented.  One of the aims will be to differentiate between nice-sounding-but-ineffective tech-for-good solutions and those that have a chance for real impact.  As a result, the course will examine challenges from a systems point of view -- to trace root causes and find the right place(s) to make lasting change.

The class will be organized into two-student project teams.  Over the semester, project teams will scope out a challenge to address; articulate possible avenues for addressing the challenge; identify key technological and non-technological factors in the challenge and its response; define metrics and evaluation criteria for a possible response; and lay out milestones for the project.  Projects will not have a particular form, but will be problem dependent.  At a high level, the first project milestone will require carefully specifying the problem being addressed and the technology to be developed.  Later milestones will depend on the project, but may include an initial prototype, alpha or beta tests, and engagement with outside stakeholders such as community groups, policymakers, nonprofits, and businesses.  At the end of the semester, teams will present/demo their projects.

Enrollment: The course is currently under restricted enrollment, so students who want to sign up would have to get a code from the instructor: barath@icsi.berkeley.edu
history.subject: CS194-032 - Computing for Social Good
